United States Department of State / Foreign relations of the United States. Conference at Quebec, 1944
			(1944)

 Proceedings of the conference, pp. 295-384
			
 PDF (32.5 MB) 



Page 296


THE SECOND QUEBE7C CONFERENCE
(See Foreign Ielations, The Conferences at Malta and Yalta, 1945,
p. 139.) A memorandum on the same meeting prepared by Assistant
Secretary of War McCloy recorded: "Mr. Morgenthau said it was
quite apparent that Mr. Churchill was violently opposed to the United
States making any Lend-Lease arrangements with France, and the
President seemed to fall in with this." (Stimson Papers)
 4. Cooperraton between the United States and the United Kingdonm
in the field of atomic energy research. Although no memoranda have
been found of conversations held at Quebec on this subject, the follow-
ing information is recorded in a memorandum of September 22, 1944
by Vannevar Bush, Director of the Office of Scientific Research and
Developmnent, concerning a meeting held at the White House that day:
 "The President then started discussing the subject [atomic
 energy] quite generally.... The President was very much in
 favor of complete interchange with the British on this subject
 after the war in all phases, and apparently on a basis where it
 would be used jointly or not at all. lie told of some of his dis-
 cusions with Mr. Churchill at Quebec along these lines. . . . The
 President's own statements in regard to post-war collaboration
 with Britain on the subject were very general indeed, but went
 very far. He pointed out his belief of the necessity for maintain-
 ing the British Empire strong, and went into some of the methods
 by which this could be brought about, which are not pertinent to
 this subject. As usual there were a number of other non-pertinent
 matters such as statements in regard to the discussions at Quebec."
 (A.E.C. Files, Tlistorical Document No. 185)
In a memorandum of September 23, 1944, Bush stated that Lord
Cherwell, who had been present at the meeting described above, "had
madle remarks which showed that he had been present at at least some"
of the Roosevelt-Churchill conversations at Quebec on atomic energy.
(A.E.C. Files, Historical Document No. 186)
 5. Aid to the Warsaw resistance. For documentation originating at
the Quebec Conference on this subject, see post, pp. 396 WT. Eden, p. 552,
records that "Poles" constituted one of the subjects of discussion
be-
tween Roosevelt and Churchill at Quebec on September 14, 1944.
AccoCrdingf to a Polish report of an Eden-MNikoTajczyk conversation
held at London on September 19, 1944, "Mr. Eden said further that at
Quebec both Prime Mdinister Churchill and President Roosevelt had
considered that the change in Stalin's position on the matter of assist-
alce, to W7arsaw [see ante, pp. 202, 203] was a good omen; in their opin-
ion it was due to their own resolute stand against him on that matter."'
(Doecutments on Polish-Soviet Relations, p. 390) According to a Pol-
ish report of a Churchill-Mikolajczyk conversation held at London
on September 29, 1944, "Churchill explained that the question of fur-
ther support for Warsaw had been one of the items discussed by him
with President Roosevelt at Quebec and that it had eventually been
decided to do everything feasible so far as the Anglo-Saxon Powers
were concerned." (Ibid., p. 396)
'According to a record by Stettinilus of a conversation with Cadogan at Wash-
ington on September 116, 1944, "Cadogan stated that the Prime Minister
had
bragged [at Quebec] about softening Uncle Joe on Poland." (Notter File,
Box
168, Stettinius Diary)
